column1: # DO NOT EDIT THIS FILE MANUALLY. IT WAS GENERATED BY ETL step 'biodiversity/latest/habitat_loss#habitat-loss'.

column2: Explore future projections of species' habitats under different agricultural interventions.

column15: title
column16: subtitle

column15: Projected habitat loss for all species in 2050: Business-as-usual
column16: Projected habitat loss for mammal, bird and amphibian species by 2050 under a business-as-usual scenario. This assumes population growth from UN medium projections; crop yield increases in line with historical rates of improvement; and dietary changes in line with projected rises in income.

column15: Projected habitat loss of mammals in 2050: Business-as-usual
column16: Projected habitat loss for mammal species by 2050 under a business-as-usual scenario. This assumes population growth from UN medium projections; crop yield increases in line with historical rates of improvement; and dietary changes in line with projected rises in income.

column15: Projected habitat loss of birds in 2050: Business-as-usual
column16: Projected habitat loss for bird species by 2050 under a business-as-usual scenario. This assumes population growth from UN medium projections; crop yield increases in line with historical rates of improvement; and dietary changes in line with projected rises in income.

column15: Projected habitat loss of amphibians in 2050: Business-as-usual

column15: Projected change in cropland area: Business-as-usual
column16: Projected change in cropland area by 2050 under a business-as-usual scenario. This assumes population growth from UN medium projections; crop yield increases in line with historical rates of improvement; and dietary changes in line with projected rises in income.

column15: Projected habitat loss for all species in 2050: Combined interventions
column16: Projected habitat loss for mammal, bird and amphibian species by 2050 if all approaches are combined: (1) closing yield gaps; (2) halving food waste; (3) global adoption of healthy diets in line with nutritional requirements; and (4) the optimisation of agricultural production to avoid the most at-risk locations for habitat loss.

column15: Projected habitat loss of mammals in 2050: Combined interventions
column16: Projected habitat loss for mammal species by 2050 if all approaches are combined: (1) closing yield gaps; (2) halving food waste; (3) global adoption of healthy diets in line with nutritional requirements; and (4) the optimisation of agricultural production to avoid the most at-risk locations for habitat loss.

column16: Projected habitat loss for amphibian species by 2050 if all approaches are combined: (1) closing yield gaps; (2) halving food waste; (3) global adoption of healthy diets in line with nutritional requirements; and (4) the optimisation of agricultural production to avoid the most at-risk locations for habitat loss.

column15: Projected change in cropland area: Combined interventions
column16: Projected change in cropland area by 2050 if all approaches are combined: (1) closing yield gaps; (2) halving food waste; (3) global adoption of healthy diets in line with nutritional requirements; and (4) the optimisation of agricultural production to avoid the most at-risk locations for habitat loss.

column15: Projected habitat loss for all species in 2050: Adoption of healthy diets
column16: Projected habitat loss for mammal, bird and amphibian species by 2050 under a scenario of global adoption of healthier diets. Diets transition to the EAT-Lancet diet which is in line with healthy calorie and nutritional requirements. For richer countries this would mean a reduction (but not elimination) of meat consumption. For poorer countries, this would mean an increase.

column15: Projected habitat loss for all species in 2050: Halve food waste
column16: Projected habitat loss for mammal, bird and amphibian species by 2050 under a scenario where consumer food waste and food losses in supply chains are reduced by 25% by 2030 and 50% by 2050.

column15: Projected habitat loss of mammals in 2050: Halve food waste
column16: Projected habitat loss for mammal species by 2050 under a scenario where consumer food waste and food losses in supply chains are reduced by 25% by 2030 and 50% by 2050.

column15: Projected habitat loss of birds in 2050: Halve food waste
column16: Projected habitat loss for bird species by 2050 under a scenario where consumer food waste and food losses in supply chains are reduced by 25% by 2030 and 50% by 2050.

column15: Projected habitat loss for all species in 2050: Close yield gaps
column16: Projected habitat loss for mammal, bird and amphibian species by 2050 under a scenario where crop yield gaps are closed. Yields increase linearly from current yields to 80% of the estimated maximum potentialÂ by 2050. Increasing yields above 80% is rarely achieved over large areas.

column15: Projected habitat loss of mammals in 2050: Close yield gaps
column16: Projected habitat loss for mammal species by 2050 under a scenario where crop yield gaps are closed. Yields increase linearly from current yields to 80% of the estimated maximum potential by 2050. Increasing yields above 80% is rarely achieved over large areas.

column15: Projected habitat loss of birds in 2050: Close yield gaps
column16: Projected habitat loss for bird species by 2050 under a scenario where crop yield gaps are closed. Yields increase linearly from current yields to 80% of the estimated maximum potential by 2050. Increasing yields above 80% is rarely achieved over large areas.

column15: Projected habitat loss of amphibians in 2050: Close yield gaps
column16: Projected habitat loss for amphibian species by 2050 under a scenario where crop yield gaps are closed. Yields increase linearly from current yields to 80% of the estimated maximum potential by 2050. Increasing yields above 80% is rarely achieved over large areas.

column15: Projected change in cropland area: Close yield gaps
column16: Projected change in cropland area by 2050 under a scenario where crop yield gaps are closed. Yields increase linearly from current yields to 80% of the estimated maximum potential by 2050. Increasing yields above 80% is rarely achieved over large areas.

column15: Projected habitat loss for all species in 2050: Optimize trade
column16: Projected habitat loss for mammal, bird and amphibian species by 2050 under a scenario where agricultural production and trade is optimized to produce food in the locations with the least risk of habitat loss. Agricultural production shifts from the 25 countries projected to have the greatest mean losses of suitable habitat across all species to countries where less than 10% of species are threatened with extinction.
column17: The goal of this scenario is to estimate the impact on biodiversity of land-use planning across international borders, avoiding expansion in the most at-risk countries. This scenario would be in conflict with food security and sovereignty, especially in countries where agriculture is a large source of income.
